Tubergan Condition Description: Whilst performing 0BwOS FP.2.2.M-2 step F.13, it was identified that the strainer flush cannot be performed as directed. F.13 calls for you to install a hose fitting and Tygon before flushing the strainer for 0FP5098. This process would require you to remove the plug in the strainer. The problem is, there is a grounding strap attached to that drain plug. This grounding strap should be moved to a more permanent location before trying to remove this plug and flushing the strainer. The second problem is the procedure never directs any closure of the isolation valve 0FP5219. This is the normal water strainer isolation valve. If this valve was left open and the strainer cap was removed (as the procedure is currently written) water would uncontrollably spew from the strainer with not procedural way to stop it. The way the procedure should be written is, bypass the normal cooling flow by opening the cooling flow bypass line, isolate the normal cooling flow, flush the normal cooling flow strainer, restore normal cooling flow configuration, flush the bypass cooling flow strainer, and finally restore the bypass cooling line configuration. Which brings me to problem three. The bypass cooling flow strainer drain is pointed directly at 0PT-FP019 'post-strainer pressure transmitter.' Not only does the strainer plug not have enough room to physically be removed with the transmitter in the way, it is not advisable to flush cooling flow directly at a flow transmitter. The strainer will need to be rotated such that it can point away from the transmitter and flushed properly. Another solution to these problems would be if a garden hose attachment was installed on the strainers similar to the old fire pump. This would include a threaded connection we could attach a garden hose to that would be routed to the drain as well as a no EPN isolation valve to be used to control flushing flow. Installation of these garden hose isolation valves would solve almost all of the problems listed above and would not require any procedure change; however, the transmitter and the grounding strap issues would still need to be addressed. As it stands now, no flushing of the 0FP03PB cooling lines will be possible. Immediate actions taken: Wrote IR Contacted Field supervisor and WEC supervisor Recommended Actions: Install simple garden hose isolation valves. Originator: KEVIN M MORES Supv Contacted: Conquest Condition Description: Performed a commonality review of surveillances for Byron/Braidwood. A difference was noted between the Essential Service Water ASME surveillances between the stations, specifically, Braidwood surveillances 1/2BwOSR 5.5.8.SX-3A/B and 1/2BwOSR 5.5.8.SX-6A/B and Byron Surveillances 1/2BOSR 5.5.8.SX.5-1c/2c. Braidwood's surveillance tests the pump specific discharge check valve whereas Byron's ASME surveillance tests the opposite train's check valve. This leads to every ASME performed at Braidwood requiring a pump swap at some point compared to Byron which can perform ASMEs on the running SX pump and limit swaps. A review of the Braidwood/Byron Logs from 1/1/2022 through present shows that Braidwood swaps SX pumps more frequently than Byron. At Braidwood, each SX pump averages ~19 pump starts per year compared to Byron which average ~9 pump starts per year per pump. The major contributors to the number of pump swaps at Braidwood are ASME surveillances, CC Heat Exchanger Flushes, valve strokes, outage lineups, and plant lineups for maintenance. To a lesser extent Chem Feed Lineup support and Forebay Outage windows also require SX pump swaps. At Byron, pumps are swapped to support ASME surveillance lineups, outage lineups, and plant lineups for maintenance. Of note, the Braidwood surveillances also cycle the lube oil inlet and returns 1/2SX2179A/B and 1/2SX2180A/B, which is not performed at Byron. These manipulations required the pump to be secured and LCO entry for the applicable pump. An ATI will be created for Ops services to separate L.O. cooler valve cycles from the ASME PM and align LCO entries in the appropriate weeks. Immediate actions taken: Discussed with IST, Engineering, Ops Services. Initiated IR for review of SX ASME Surveillances to align with Byron and limit pump swaps. Recommended Actions: IST to evaluate Braidwood surveillances 1/2BwOSR 5.5.8.SX-3A/B and 1/2BwOSR 5.5.8.SX-6A/B to check opposite train discharge check valve vice train specific to limit SX pump swap during each ASME. Include evaluation of lube oil cooler cycling in the review and work with Ops services for best scheduling practice. ATI for services to submit PMMR to separate L.O. cooler valve cycles from the ASME PM and align LCO entries in the appropriate weeks. PCRA to Ops Support to update Braidwood surveillances 1/2BwOSR 5.5.8.SX-3A/B and 1/2BwOSR 5.5.8.SX-6A/B based on IST Recommendations and Byron procedure. Originator: MATTHEW F TAMMEN Supv Contacted: Anjum Condition Description: While reviewing BwOP CO-5T2 for manual actuation of CO2 to the UCSR it was found that Pushbutton #2 for Zone 2EE3 (2S-50) has its location as being given: "2HS-CO072 AUX BLDG 463' P-20 FROM TURB BLDG" While the location 463' P-20 matches Asset Suite's given location, the description "FROM TURB BLDG" is potentially dangerous in this context. The location of this actuator is shown on Pre-Fire Plan #34 and #36 in Zone 2EE4 next to the door to zone 2EE3. This is on the "Clean" Side of the UCSR, as opposed to the other actuators which are on the RCA side of the rope. The intent of this description was probably to delineate this difference, but it makes no sense in the context of this procedure. The reason you would be manually actuating CO2 to zone 2EE3 is because 2EE3 is on fire and Halon failed to actuate automatically (but potentially could actuate at any time). Manual CO2 pushbutton 1 is in a better location for actuation but could also have failed. If you wanted to use Station 2 to blanket the zone it would only make sense to access this pushbutton from the Aux Building Side, cross the Rad Rope (which due to the fire, radiological issues are secondary concerns), and actuate the station from there. To access the pushbutton "FROM TURB BLDG" would require an EO to pass through 2EE3 (which is the zone presumably on fire). Following the Fire Response, RP can be notified to adjust the Rad Boundary to all of 2EE4 and follow up with surveys. It is also worth mentioning that procedures for Manual Actuation of CO2 (BwOP CO-5 series) have been put into "Dynamic Procedure" format. This is completely inappropriate. Imagine, the UCSR is on fire, a location immediately above the Main Control Room (probably with many spurious system actuations occurring due to electrical shorts): is it desired for Operations to stop to get an iPad and assign manual actuation of CO2 to someone, then bring the iPad with them hoping to not have technical issues (i.e. mandatory updates, pages loading mid procedure, stylus issues, etc.)? Can a situation be described where utilizing this procedure for its intended purpose during a fire would be appropriate in this format? This procedure should only be in paper format and staged for use as it always has been in binders in the plant. It seems like a gross oversight of the organization to allow this to have happened. Peoples' lives could be at stake during a fire response. If this is simple blind adherence to transitioning all procedures to Dynamic format regardless of who may be harmed in the process, then we should be ashamed as an organization. Personnel Safety should be the station's priority. Immediate actions taken: Notified Supervisor, Generated IR Recommended Actions: Revise location description of Pushbutton 2 in BwOP CO-5T2.
